xxl.core.cursors.groupers

Class SortBasedGrouper<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
      • xxl.core.cursors.groupers.SortBasedGrouper<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the elements returned by this iteration.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterator<Cursor<E>>, Cursor<Cursor<E>>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SortBasedGrouper

    public class SortBasedGrouper<E>
extends AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
    A sort-based implementation of the group operator. A sort-based grouper partitions input data into groups (lazy evaluation). A binary predicate (or boolean function) is used to compare the current element with the last element consumed from the underlying input iteration. If this predicate returns true a new group starts, otherwise the next element delivered from the underlying iteration belongs to the same group. A call to next returns a cursor pointing to the next group!

    Precondition: The input cursor has to be sorted!

    Note: If the input iteration is given by an object of the class Iterator, i.e., it does not support the peek operation, it is internally wrapped to a cursor.

    Example usage: 

         SortBasedGrouper<Integer> sortBasedGrouper = new SortBasedGrouper<Integer>(
         new DiscreteRandomNumber(new JavaDiscreteRandomWrapper(100), 50),
         new Predicate<Integer>() {
             public boolean invoke(Integer previous, Integer next) {
                 return previous > next;
             }
         }
     );
 
     sortBasedGrouper.open();
 
     Cursor<Integer> sequence;
     while (sortBasedGrouper.hasNext()) {
         sequence = sortBasedGrouper.next();
         while (sequence.hasNext())
             System.out.print(sequence.next() + "; ");
         System.out.flush();
         System.out.println();
     }
 
     sortBasedGrouper.close();
    This example partitions 50 random integers with maximum value '99' into groups. A new group starts if the predicate returns true. That is the case when the next integer value delivered by the input cursor is lower than the previously returned integer value. So this instance of a sort-based grouper returns all monotonous ascending sequences contained in the input iteration by lazy evaluation.

    See Also:
    Iterator, Cursor, HashGrouper, NestedLoopsGrouper

                        Predicate<? super E> predicate)
        Creates a new sort-based grouper. If an iterator is given to this constructor it is wrapped to a cursor.
        Parameters:
        iterator - the input iteration to be grouped.
        predicate - the binary predicate deciding if a new group starts.

      • SortBasedGrouper

        public SortBasedGrouper(Iterator<E> iterator,
                        Function<? super E,Boolean> function)
        Creates a new sort-based grouper. If an iterator is given to this constructor it is wrapped to a cursor and the given boolean function is internally wrapped to a predicate.
        Parameters:
        iterator - the input iteration to be grouped.
        function - a boolean function deciding if a new group starts.

    • Method Detail

      • open

        public void open()
        Opens the sort-based grouper, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open the input iteration, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

        Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

        Specified by:
        open in interface Cursor<Cursor<E>>
        Overrides:
        open in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes the sort-based grouper. Signals it to clean up resources, close the input iteration, etc. After a call to close calls to methods like next or peek are not guarantied to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the sort-based grouper remains in the state "closed".
        Specified by:
        close in interface Cursor<Cursor<E>>
        Overrides:
        close in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>

      • hasNextObject

        protected boolean hasNextObject()
        Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.) This happens when the specified predicate evaluated for the previous element and the next element of the input iteration, determined by its peek method is true. Then a new group starts.
        Specified by:
        hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
        Returns:
        true if the sort-based grouper has more elements, otherwise false.

      • nextObject

        protected Cursor<E> nextObject()
        Returns the next element in the iteration (a cursor iterating over the next group!). In this case that means the next group of elements that are equal concerning the user defined predicate is returned as a new cursor.
        Important: LAZY EVALUATION is used!
        With the help of this cursor instance the caller is able to traverse and operate with the group of elements. The delivered cursor does definitely not support the methods close and reset.
        Specified by:
        nextObject in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
        Returns:
        the next element in the iteration (a cursor iterating over the next group!).

      • reset

        public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
        Resets the sort-based grouper to its initial state (optional operation). So the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again.
        Specified by:
        reset in interface Cursor<Cursor<E>>
        Overrides:
        reset in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset method is not supported by the input cursor.

      • supportsReset

        public boolean supportsReset()
        Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the sort-based grouper. Otherwise it returns false.
        Specified by:
        supportsReset in interface Cursor<Cursor<E>>
        Overrides:
        supportsReset in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
        Returns:
        true if the reset operation is supported by the sort-based grouper, otherwise false.
